wordpressPost.title: Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup 5/1/2015
wordpressPost.content:
The WeSpire Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup aggregates the top employee engagement articles from around the industry to keep you informed and inspire positive impact in your organization.

The Hook Model: The First Step to Designing the Employee Engagement Experience

Nir Eyal, entrepreneur and author of the book, Hooked: How to Build Habit-Forming Products, offers advice on how to choose technology that engage employees. Tips include thinking about which apps engage you the most and why and looking for apps that use the hook model: triggers, action, reward, investment.

10 Steps to a Dynamic Corporate Responsibility Annual Report

Annual reports are a very effective way to brand your CSR program and outline the efforts and accomplishments of the last 12 months. With the goal to captivate, inform, and excite your readers, the author offers 10 sections you should think about including. Our favorite: The Family Photo, the data, and compare and contrast.

4 Methods to Increase Employee Productivity

According to Deloitte, last year only 8% of employees believed their performance management process drove business value and 75% of respondents rated performance management as important’ or very important’ for 2015. To help combat productivity issues, the author recommends to relax on internet restrictions, consistently measure overall employee activity and productivity, set goals and use results to help employees grow, and account for brain breaks.

100 Best Companies to Work For

This week, Fortune released it’s 18th report with Great Place to Work on the most treasured and coveted workplaces in the nation based on their extensive and highly competitive survey. The Top 10 Best Companies to WorK for include: Google, The Boston Consulting Group, ACUITY, SAS Institute, Robert W. Baird, Edward Jones, Wegmans Food Markets, salesforce, Genentech, and Camden Property Trust.

5 Ways How Leaders Achieve Genuine Employee Engagement

Research suggests a strong link between personal learning/development and motivation. When combined with a culture of trust, an organization is rewarded with a high performing and engaged workforce. The author suggests: 1) Be open about your expectations, successes, and failures, 2) Encourage dissent, 3) Share the profit, share the plan, 4) Avoid stratospheric executive compensation, and 5) Give people the flexibility to wear multiple hats.
